transcript.speaker: **Interview Transcript
transcript.text: Roomba 694 User Feedback**

transcript.speaker: **Interviewer
transcript.text: ** Chris (Corporate Representative, iRobot)

transcript.speaker: **Interviewee
transcript.text: ** Dennis (Customer, Roomba 694) **(The interview begins with Chris calling Dennis at a pre-arranged time.)**

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** Hi Dennis, thanks so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Chris, and I'm with the iRobot customer insights team. We really appreciate you sharing your experience with the Roomba 694, and we'd love to just chat a bit more about your review. Is this still a good time for you?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** Hey Chris, yeah, absolutely. No problem at all, I just got off a call, so I'm free for a bit. Happy to help out.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** Excellent. And just to confirm, you're Dennis, correct?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** That's me. Dennis, from Austin.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** Great. So Dennis, we really value direct feedback from our users like yourself. Your review was quite detailed, and it gave us a lot to think about. I just wanted to dive a little deeper, hear more in your own words. To start, you mentioned in your review that you were looking for something for daily maintenance because you work long hours. Could you elaborate a bit on what specifically motivated you to choose the Roomba 694 over other options you might have considered?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** Sure. Uh, well, yeah, like I said, my job in construction, it, uh, it keeps me pretty busy. Long days, and when I get home, the last thing I wanna do is pull out a vacuum. I mean, my house isn't huge, about 1500 square feet, but it's enough to get dusty quickly, especially with the dog I've got, even if he's not a super shedder. I needed something that could just run on its own. I looked at a few different brands, honestly. But Roomba, you know, it’s the name that everyone knows. It’s like the Kleenex of robot vacuums. And the 694 was, uh, it was presented as an entry-level model. The price point was decent enough for what I was hoping to get – something that just handles the day-to-day. I figured starting with a well-known brand was a safer bet.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** That makes a lot of sense. The brand recognition definitely plays a big role for many of our customers. And you mentioned the dog – is that a relatively recent addition, or have you had him for a while?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** Oh, I've had Gus for a few years now. He's a good boy, but, uh, yeah, between him tracking in a bit of dirt and just the usual dust, it adds up. I used to just do a quick sweep every other day, or pull out the upright vacuum once a week, but that just started feeling like wasted time, you know? Time I could be using to actually relax or, uh, honestly, just sleep.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** Absolutely, I hear you. The promise of saving time and making life a little easier is exactly what these devices are designed for. In your review, you also highlighted some positive aspects, like its effectiveness on hard floors and low-pile carpets, and the user-friendly app. Could you tell me a bit more about what you find most satisfying about its performance in those areas?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** Yeah, when it works, it *works*. I mean, on the hardwood floors, especially in the kitchen and living room, it really does a good job of picking up the surface stuff – crumbs, dust bunnies, Gus's hair. I definitely notice a difference when it's been running regularly. It keeps that "just vacuumed" look, which is great. And the app, honestly, that's probably the best part. Being able to set it to run at, like, 7 AM every weekday while I'm already out the door, that's awesome. I love coming home and seeing the main areas looking noticeably cleaner. It's, uh, it’s a tangible benefit. And emptying the bin, that's pretty painless too. Just pull it out, dump it, done.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** That convenience of the app and coming home to a cleaner space sounds really valuable to you. It's great to hear those features are hitting the mark. Now, you also spent quite a bit of time discussing the "downsides," and the first one you brought up was its navigation – the "bump and go" system. Could you describe a typical scenario where this random navigation becomes a real frustration for you?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** Oh man, where do I even begin with that? It's like watching a really inefficient worker. You know, you expect a certain level of, I don't know, *logic*? But it just bumps into something, turns, bumps into something else, turns. I've literally watched it clean the same square foot of floor, meticulously, for five minutes straight, while there's a visible dust bunny three feet away that it completely ignores. Or, uh, it'll spend ages in one corner of the living room and just completely miss the dining area right next to it. It’s infuriating because it means I can never truly trust that it’s actually cleaned the whole floor. From an analytical perspective, the pathing is just… inefficient and incomplete. It’s guesswork if it’s actually done anything useful beyond a very localized spot clean.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** I understand completely. That lack of systematic coverage must be incredibly frustrating, especially when you're relying on it to handle a chore autonomously. Does that mean you find yourself running it multiple times just to *hope* it eventually covers the missed spots, or do you end up having to supplement its cleaning with a traditional vacuum more often than you'd like?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** Both, actually. Sometimes I’ll run it twice in a row, thinking, “Okay, maybe *this* time it’ll get the other half of the kitchen.” But that just doubles the battery usage and the noise. More often, yeah, I still have to pull out my regular vacuum for a proper, thorough clean, probably once a week or every other week. The Roomba is really just for the superficial stuff, like I said in the review. It just means I haven't fully eliminated that chore, which was the whole point, right?

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** Right, that certainly undermines the core benefit. You also mentioned it getting stuck frequently. What are the most common culprits in your home that cause it to get wedged or tangled?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** It's usually the same things. Chair legs are a big one – the base of the dining chairs, it just seems to wedge itself right under them and then can't back out. Or the edges of my area rugs. They're low-pile, but if the edge curls even slightly, it just gets caught. And cables, man. I try to tuck them away, but there's always one that somehow becomes a trap. Power strips behind the TV, lamp cords. I get a "Roomba stuck" notification on my phone almost every single time it runs. And then I have to go find it, usually under a couch or in a corner, lift it out, sometimes untangle its brushes from hair or a stray thread. It happens so often that it just feels like it's demanding more attention than it's worth sometimes.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** That's a significant burden. It sounds like the promise of a "hands-free" device is constantly interrupted by these interventions. Have you tried any specific strategies to "Roomba-proof" your home, like lifting chairs or moving cables, or is it just too much of an ongoing effort?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** I've tried. I really have. Before I set it to run, I'll do a quick sweep of the main areas, try to move loose cables or pick up anything obvious. But you can't really move all your furniture every day, right? And I live here, things get used, things get shifted. So it's not a practical daily solution. Plus, sometimes it gets stuck on things I wouldn't even *think* would be an issue, like a slightly uneven transition strip between floor types. It's just very… finicky.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** Mmm, "finicky" is a good word for that kind of behavior. You also noted that the brushes require regular cleaning. Is that something you find particularly annoying, or just part of the routine?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** It's annoying. It's not *hard* to do, but it's another manual chore. My hair, Gus's hair, it just gets wrapped around those brushes so tightly. And if you don't clean it, the performance drops. So it's not truly autonomous. It needs regular grooming itself. It's just another point of friction where the "set it and forget it" ideal falls apart.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** I see. And speaking of performance, you mentioned the battery life and noise level. Could you elaborate on how those impact your overall satisfaction?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** Battery life is, uh, adequate for smaller sections. But to cover my entire main floor, which is maybe 1000 square feet, it usually needs to go back to the base to recharge mid-cycle. Which, fine, it does that, but then it's down for an hour or so before it starts again, and that just lengthens the whole cleaning process. And sometimes, it just… dies before it makes it back to the charger. I've found it sitting dead in the middle of a room more than once. The noise, it's not like a jet engine, but it's definitely noticeable. It's comparable to a regular vacuum, honestly. So if I'm home trying to read or work on something for my doctorate, or even just watch TV, it's disruptive. That's why I primarily schedule it for when I'm out.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** That makes perfect sense. So, given these limitations, if you were to compare the Roomba 694 to your previous cleaning methods – the manual sweeping and upright vacuuming – how would you weigh the trade-offs? Are the benefits still significant enough to outweigh the frustrations?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** That's a good question. I think… yeah, the benefits are still there, to a degree. The convenience of it handling the *surface* mess while I'm out is genuinely helpful. It means I'm not coming home to a visibly dirty floor. It takes the edge off. But it hasn't replaced my other vacuum, and it hasn't completely removed the chore. It's more like a really good helper for the quick maintenance, rather than a full solution. It's, uh, it's an assistant, not a replacement. So the trade-off is I get some time back, but I also have to babysit it quite a bit, which is, you know, not ideal.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** That's a very clear way to put it – an assistant, not a replacement. If you could wave a magic wand and improve one or two things about the Roomba 694, what would be at the top of your list?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** Definitely the navigation. Hands down. If it could map my home, learn the layout, and follow a systematic pattern, that would solve so many of its problems. It wouldn't miss entire sections, it wouldn't clean the same spot over and over. That's, like, the core issue for me. And, uh, if it could be smarter about obstacles, too. Less getting stuck. Maybe some better object detection or a different brush design that's less prone to tangles. Those two things would make a massive difference.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** Intelligent navigation and improved obstacle avoidance – got it. If a competitor came out with a robot vacuum that offered those features reliably, even at a slightly higher price point, would that make you consider switching away from iRobot?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** Oh, absolutely. Yeah. If there was a product that could consistently clean my entire space, without getting stuck all the time, that would be a game changer. I mean, my income is good, I value my time. I wouldn’t mind paying a bit more for a truly autonomous and efficient cleaning experience. The 694 was entry-level, and I got what I paid for, I guess. But if a more advanced model, even from iRobot, offered true mapping and better navigation, I'd definitely consider upgrading. But if a competitor did it first, and did it well, I wouldn't hesitate to switch. The brand loyalty isn't so strong that I'd stick with something that doesn't meet my core needs.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** That's really insightful feedback, Dennis. It's clear that while the entry-level convenience is appealing, there's a strong desire for more advanced functionality to truly fulfill that "hands-free" promise. Finally, on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being extremely dissatisfied and 10 being extremely satisfied, what would you rate your overall satisfaction with the Roomba 694 as it stands today?

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** Hmm. That’s tough. I gave it a 3 in my review, which felt right then. After talking it through… I'd probably still stick with a 3. It's not terrible, it does *some* good. But it's got significant shortcomings that prevent it from being a truly great product. It's just… okay. Could be a lot better.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** A solid 3. Thank you, Dennis. That's a very clear assessment, and it helps us a lot. We really appreciate you taking the time to share your honest thoughts and experiences with us. Your feedback is incredibly valuable as we look to improve our products.

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** No problem, Chris. Happy to contribute. Hopefully, it helps you guys make some improvements.

transcript.speaker: **Chris
transcript.text: ** It absolutely will. Thanks again, Dennis, and have a great rest of your day.

transcript.speaker: **Dennis
transcript.text: ** You too. Bye. **(End of Interview)**
